author: Motschekiebchen
body:
I mean you could argue completely different.
It’s true that crypto went through cyclic movements in the past and that the market is currently pumping strongly.
But all those investment or adaptions from Tesla, Paypal or the listing of Coinbase could be seen as a sign of mass adoption. So maybe no cyclic bear market is coming for crypto and it remains relatively stable.
It’s all very speculative and you might as well ask your magic 8-Ball.
In my opinion this is a very interesting time to start to invest in crypto with good fundamentals. But I definitely would only start with a part of your money.

author: everybodysaysso
body:
BABA seem to be gaining some attention on this sub and rightly so IMO. While talking about its valuation and growth are good. I think that the discussion on its venture arm is severely overlooked. I have looked into their investments in India and they will come out as bandits when these startups IPO. For example, BABA has invested in some of the biggest startups in India in their respective fields: Fintech (Paytm), e-com (Snapdeal), daily fruits/veggies/groceries (BigBasket), online delivery (Zomato). All these companies are highly successful and will be north of $50B in 5 years as more and more Indians get online. 

Last year because of escalation at government level between India and China, Alibaba halted their Indian investments. But I think they have already invested in Paypal, Doordash and Amazon of India and have even used the same playbook in other countries. 

If China FUD was not a thing, Alibaba would make FANG look like boomers when their startup investments come to IPO. But again may be I am missing a piece of the puzzle somewhere. But for me, Alibaba itself is doing great, but I will continue buying since its my best way to gain exposure in upcoming behemoths in developing World.

author: EvaUnit343
body:
I truly, truly do not understand the long term bull thesis for COIN. 

If corn is adopted, other competitors (like PayPal) step in and drive down COIN’s absurd premiums, losing market share. 

If corn is not adopted, COIN goes to zero. 

As much as I want Cathie to sit on my face, she’s wrong on this one...

author: iBifteki
body:
This is what I keep seeing as well.

Many genuienly big cap, good companies (strong guidance, free cashflow, profitability, debt ratio, etc) are already down 20-25% from ATH ($TSM, $PYPL, etc)

Other growths like $TDOC and $BYND are down 50%+.

I don't understand how much more punishment these need to receive for a reversal to start taking place.

And what shall we do, buy bonds from a historially indebted US Treasury?

I feel like these inflation news are priced in now, and actually promising that the US economy is not totally fucked. Imagine if we got disinflation. That would be a huge issue.

If we drop another 10% I am buying all the way down, in my humble opinion, I feel like companies like Apple will keep killing it.

NIKOLA: 9,400X (it’s not a typo over 9K) if they don’t cure cancer on Friday with their earnings report they are gonna crash.  

OCGN: 70X. They is fucked as well. And not only for their high PS.  

MVIS: 250X and that’s after they collapsed.  

This is good info use it.  Stop losing $$$

author: lattiboy
body:
I think PayPal earnings are the most important of the whole season. They’re basically the 500lb gorilla of Fintech and they’ve been getting beaten down since February. If they print money like i think they will, it could send the whole sector (and tech more broadly) into a turn around. 

Just my two cents, and I’ve got a lot of ARKF options riding on this that I’m down a fair bit on….

author: WRL23
body:
I'd agree for that with any Crypto not just doge

It's slowly becoming accepted, understood, trusted, etc.. like how paypal existed for years but (let's be honest here) not that many people used at least not often. Then came along venmo and other shit like that.. let's call those alt-pay apps. People slowly but surely were accepting it, using it etc.

No not the best 3 example but hopefully you see my point. That's why I  stand by any good Crypto news is good news for all Crypto.. alts or not. The more the good vibes go out to media etc the more people get used to hearing it and then accepting it and eventually using it.

Does grandma still write checks? Yep! But those situations are less and less and do not reflect the direction we're heading.

author: The_Contrarian01
body:
Futures are higher this morning, rebounding from the ‘Yellen head-fake’ that caused a bunch of selling yesterday afternoon. Small caps are leading the move higher, with the Russell 2000 up 0.7%. Nasdaq is up 0.6%. S&P and Dow up about 0.3%. Russell and Nasdaq also saw the brunt of the damage yesterday, giving up almost 2% each.

We do get to hear from a couple of FOMC members: Eric Rosengren, Loretta Mester, and Charles Evans. Not sure if they’re taking questions but if so you can bet they’ll be asked about Yellen’s comments. 

My thoughts on Yellen and the Fed: Need to listen to the audio. Not gonna type it.

ADP payrolls are due out at 0815. Economists expecting 800k jobs added in April, quite a bit more than the 517k from March. We also get ISM services data at 10am. These are a couple of key reports where the health of the economy is concerned. As always, you need to watch for the Goldilocks scenario: too hot and it means inflation and Fed tightening. Too cold and the economy is not recovering quickly or strongly enough. Though nowadays, maybe the ‘too cold’ scenario is preferred.

More earnings today as well: Hilton Worldwide just came out with a miss. GM, Allstate, and Etsy report later. After the bell we get Uber, Booking Holdings, and PayPal.

author: The_Contrarian01
body:
Good morning contrarians!

Futures are higher this morning, rebounding from the ‘Yellen head-fake’ that caused a bunch of selling yesterday afternoon. Small caps are leading the move higher, with the Russell 2000 up 0.7%. Nasdaq is up 0.6%. S&P and Dow up about 0.3%. Russell and Nasdaq also saw the brunt of the damage yesterday, giving up almost 2% each.

We do get to hear from a couple of FOMC members: Eric Rosengren, Loretta Mester, and Charles Evans. Not sure if they’re taking questions but if so you can bet they’ll be asked about Yellen’s comments. 

My thoughts on Yellen and the Fed: Need to listen to the audio. Not gonna type it.

ADP payrolls are due out at 0815. Economists expecting 800k jobs added in April, quite a bit more than the 517k from March. We also get ISM services data at 10am. These are a couple of key reports where the health of the economy is concerned. As always, you need to watch for the Goldilocks scenario: too hot and it means inflation and Fed tightening. Too cold and the economy is not recovering quickly or strongly enough. Though nowadays, maybe the ‘too cold’ scenario is preferred.

More earnings today as well: Hilton Worldwide just came out with a miss. GM, Allstate, and Etsy report later. After the bell we get Uber, Booking Holdings, and PayPal.

author: mcgravier
body:
> But all those investment or adaptions from Tesla, Paypal or the listing of Coinbase could be seen as a sign of mass adoption.

Back in 2017 Bitcoin looked to be mass adopted as well. Microsoft, Dell, Steam, Tigerdirect, Wargaming and many other companies big and small started to accept Bitcoin payments for their products, but it went nowhere - mostly because technology was immature, and couldn't cope with the massive traffic. 

This time might be different, but it may misfire again as well.

author: dudetalking
body:
I agree with Munger this current mania is not healthy for society, and will be very destructive.  When you see things like Weed Stocks, Gambling Stocks, Vaporware cyrptos, excess financial leverage.

Also systemic risk is brewing everywhere, especially in the Defi space. That is the new unregulated dark pools, except this time its going to destroy retail when it unravels.  Its amazing that there is zero concern for these giants like paypal, square, becoming quasi banks.

Definitely going to be a fun movie to watch.

I think the boom/bust cycle could be faster than people anticipate. This morning on CNBC a advisor already had mapped the entire year, a 10% correction 2 months before the new tax plan, and until then the market can go sideways or up. Zero risk apparently.

As someone who was around and traded in the .com, this bubble is dwarfing .com mania.

author: adayofjoy
body:
> Buy what you believe in

I believed in BABA, JD and PYPL and those were some of my largest individual stock picks. Paypal's done alright but is only barely keeping up with the market from the point I bought it, while the other two have sorely underperformed the market.

> Ignore the noise

I wish I didn't ignore all the people telling me to sell my growth stocks and rotate into value as well as all the negative news regarding China's crackdown on tech giants. Many opportunities were missed.

> Hold LONG term

I trust that in 5 years the recent volatility in these stocks will just be a blip on a chart, but the question still remains if I would've been better off putting that money into an S&P 500 index fund instead.

author: mediumthings888
body:
WELL Healthcare (WELL.TO)

Trading at just over $7 below last raise from 9.80.  Earnings call is on Tuesday and they have never missed.  They have started expanding into the US.  They really are just getting started.  The CEO sold his last company to PayPal and was with that company for 20 years.   Extremely capable management team.  Li Ka Shing one of the richest people in the world has invested over $130m so far.  He also participated in the $9.80 round.  Also all of their management participated in that round also.

author: oodex
body:
He is not dumb, he is very smart. He knows what he talks about and plays with people. Note that I don't envy him or anything, I just state what happened in the last 2 years. He took a shit company (shit compared to other existing companies) and made it one of the most valued in the entire world on the stock market, he went into all the businesses that have a lot of talk & promising future with EV, AI, Space and what not. I don't think his companies have no value behind them, in fact I think he will be a major shake up in the current industry model of how a CEO will act and will be viewed in the future, but I don't think that he takes a lot serious anymore. He has more than enough money to retire and pay bills for the next 100 generations of his, if wanted. I would recommend you reading more about Elon Musk's history in general, his role in Paypal and what exactly he did, his affair with Amber Heard while she was with Johnny Depp, his start with Tesla and how it progressed.

Note that this has been done a couple of times in the past, mostly reminds me of Theranos and Elizabeth Holmes, who faked everything until it blew up. She was one of the most promising persons of that time, but imploded into nothing (though with a ton of money). Contrary to that Musk actually has a lot to show, but definitely not the value it currently has on the market. That's good for believers to not fall back to 0.

author: SirGasleak
body:
I own both SQ and PYPL.  If you think fintech is a growth industry, you have to own the big dogs in the space.  I also own PSFE, which is stupidly undervalued.

And SQ is only overvalued if you're looking at PE.  On a P/S metric it isn't overvalued at all.  And with a market cap of $94B it still has a lot of room to grow.
